anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers companyferred by the proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution of India, the Governor of U.P. is pleased to make the following general rule

concepts.unlisted_label: Article 309 of the Constitution of India
concepts.unlisted_description: Power of executive to make rules regulating service conditions, proviso referenced in UP temporary service rule.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1734 of 1968 dated 11th October, 1968. regulating the termination of services of temporary Government servants Notwithstanding anything to the companytrary in any existing rules and orders on the subject, the services of a Government servant in temporary service shall be liable to termination at any time by numberice in writing given either by the Government servant to the appointing authority, or by the appointing authority to the Government servant.

concepts.interpretation: Pay in lieu of notice may substitute without requiring simultaneous payment; differs from CCS Rule 5 as no condition of timing for payment.
concepts.unlisted_label: U.P. Temporary Government Servants Termination Rule
concepts.unlisted_description: Rule made under Article 309 for termination of temporary servants by notice or pay in lieu, distinguished from CCS Rule 5.

issues.text: whether the order dated September 25, 1968 terminating the services of the respondent, a temporary Government servant, was in accordance with the provisions of Rule 5 of the Central Service Temporary Service Rules 1965

anchor.surface_text: The only question involved in this appeal is, whether the order dated September 25, 1968 terminating the services of the respondent, a temporary Government servant, was in accordance with the provisions of Rule 5 of the Central Service  Temporary Service  Rules 1965, hereinafter referred to as the Rules.

issues.text: whether the order of termination of service can be sustained because of absence of payment on the 25th September

anchor.surface_text: The question is, whether the order of termination of service can be sustained because of absence of payment on the 25th September.

issues.text: whether the rule is capable of the only interpretation that the order of termination can be upheld if the requisite amount in terms of the rule was paid into the hands of the employee or made available to him at the same time as he was served with the order

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the authorities which were cited at the Bar, it appears to us that the rule is capable of the only interpretation that the order of termination can be upheld if the requisite amount in terms of the rule was paid into the hands of the employee of made available to him at the same time as he was served with the order.

issues.text: whether the termination of service becomes effective as soon as the order is served on the Government servant irrespective of the question as to when the payment due to him is to be made

anchor.surface_text: The rule does number lend itself to the interpretation that the termination of service becomes effective as soon as the order is served on the Government servant irrespective of the question as to when the payment due to him is to be made.

anchor.surface_text: We need number pause to companysider the question as to what would be the effect if there was a bonafide mistake as to the amount which is to be paid.

arguments.claim: The rule is capable of the only interpretation that the order of termination can be upheld if the requisite amount was paid into the hands of the employee or made available to him at the same time as he was served with the order

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the authorities which were cited at the Bar, it appears to us that the rule is capable of the only interpretation that the order of termination can be upheld if the requisite amount in terms of the rule was paid into the hands of the employee of made available to him at the same time as he was served with the order.

arguments.claim: Rule 5(1)(a) gives the Government as well as the employee a right to put an end to the service by a notice in writing

anchor.surface_text: Rule, 5  1    a  gives the Government as well as the employee a right to put an end to the service by a notice in writing.

arguments.claim: The proviso gives the Government an additional right to terminate forthwith by payment to him of a sum equivalent to the amount of his pay plus allowances

anchor.surface_text: Under rule 1  b  the period prescribed for such notice is one month. The proviso to sub-r.  b  however gives the Government an additional right in that it gives an option to the Government not to retain the services of the employee till the expiry of the period of the notice if it so chooses to terminate the service at any time it can do so forthwith by payment to him of a sum equivalent to the amount of his pay plus allowances for the period of the notice at the same rate at which he was drawing them immediately before the termination of his services, or, as the case may be, for the period by which such notice falls short of one month.

arguments.claim: To be effective the termination of service has to be simultaneous with the payment to the employee of whatever is due to him

anchor.surface_text: At the risk of repetition, we may note that the operative words of the proviso are the services of any such Government servant may be terminated forthwith by payment. To put the matter in a nutshell, to be effective the termination of service has to be simultaneous with the payment to the employee of whatever is due to him.

arguments.claim: The rule does not lend itself to the interpretation that the termination of service becomes effective as soon as the order is served irrespective of when the payment is made

anchor.surface_text: The rule does not lend itself to the interpretation that the termination of service becomes effective as soon as the order is served on the Government servant irrespective of the question as to when the payment due to him is to be made.

arguments.claim: If precise words used are plain and unambiguous, construe them in their ordinary sense without limiting by policy considerations

anchor.surface_text: As has often been said that if the precise words used are plain and unambiguous, we are bound to construe them in their ordinary sense and not to limit plain words in an Act of Parliament by considerations of policy, if it be policy, as to which minds may differ and as to which decisions. may vary.-see Craies on Statute Law, Sixth Edition, pages 86 and 92.

arguments.claim: It would be almost impossible to give effect to the proviso if payment has to be made at the time the order is served due to procedural requirements

anchor.surface_text: It was argued that it would, in the ordinary course of things, be almost impossible for the authorities to give effect to the proviso if payment has to be made at the time the order of termination is served on the employee. It was submitted that before any payment can be made by Government, sanction has to be taken and some time must elapse before the necessary procedure is complied with and money obtained either from the treasury or a cheque made out to cover the amount due to the employee.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hould be calculated so that it companyld be offered to the employee at the time when the order of termination is served on him. There can be numberdif

arguments.court_reasoning: Possible with prior calculation during enquiry time before serving order

arguments.claim: If High Court construction maintained, appointing authority could never terminate immediately even in public interest

anchor.surface_text: It was also argued that if the construction given by the High Court to the rule is to be maintained, the appointing authority could never ask, the employee to go at once even when it found that it was necessary in the interest of Government to require him to do so.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: dent that the company- struction of the rule should be such as would mitigate the rigour of an order of termination inasmuch as where numberice of a f

arguments.court_reasoning: Difficult to contemplate spur of moment decision; normally follows enquiry allowing time for calculation

arguments.claim: Construction of rule should mitigate rigour of termination order; full notice allows preparation, sudden depends on mercy

anchor.surface_text: It was suggested on behalf of the respondent that the con- struction of the rule should be such as would mitigate the rigour of an order of termination inasmuch as where notice of a full month is given the Government servant knows that he will have to find some other employment without delay and he can make his arrangements accordingly but if he is to be asked to leave at once and to depend on the mercy of the Government as to when it will pay him for the period of the notice, it would be very hard on the employee.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Constitution of India, the Governor of U.P. is pleased to make the following general rule Civil Appeal No. 1734 of 1968 dated 11th October, 1968. regu

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to express view on reason; must give effect to plain meaning

arguments.claim: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Dinanath Rai supports that payment need not be simultaneous

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn to a decision of this Court which had been cited on behalf of the appellant in the High Court- The state of uttar Pradesh v. Dinanath Rai 1  There the rule was differently worded.

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule differently worded; no condition as to when payment to be given, unlike here where payment is condition for forthwith termination

arguments.claim: The UP rule does not say pay should be given at the time notice issued; difficult to ascribe such intention
arguments.court_reasoning: Essential difference; UP rule substitutes pay without timing condition

holdings.text: The rule is capable of the only interpretation that the order of termination can be upheld if the requisite amount in terms of the rule was paid into the hands of the employee or made available to him at the same time as he was served with the order.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the authorities which were cited at the Bar, it appears to us that the rule is capable of the only interpretation that the order of termination can be upheld if the requisite amount in terms of the rule was paid into the hands of the employee of made available to him at the same time as he was served with the order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of proviso to Rule 5(1)(b) links 'terminated forthwith by payment' requiring simultaneity; operative words dictate this meaning.

holdings.text: To be effective the termination of service has to be simultaneous with the payment to the employee of whatever is due to him.

anchor.surface_text: At the risk of repetition, we may note that the operative words of the proviso are the services of any such Government servant may be terminated forthwith by payment. To put the matter in a nutshell, to be effective the termination of service has to be simultaneous with the payment to the employee of whatever is due to him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Operative words 'may be terminated forthwith by payment' make payment integral and simultaneous for effectiveness.

holdings.text: The rule does not lend itself to the interpretation that the termination of service becomes effective as soon as the order is served on the Government servant irrespective of the question as to when the payment due to him is to be made.

anchor.surface_text: The rule does not lend itself to the interpretation that the termination of service becomes effective as soon as the order is served on the Government servant irrespective of the question as to when the payment due to him is to be made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso wording conditions forthwith termination on payment, not service alone; otherwise worded differently if intended.

holdings.text: If the precise words used are plain and unambiguous, we are bound to construe them in their ordinary sense and not to limit plain words in an Act of Parliament by considerations of policy.

anchor.surface_text: As has often been said that if the precise words used are plain and unambiguous, we are bound to construe them in their ordinary sense and not to limit plain words in an Act of Parliament by considerations of policy, if it be policy, as to which minds may differ and as to which decisions. may vary.-see Craies on Statute Law, Sixth Edition, pages 86 and 92.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal rule of construction mandates ordinary meaning for plain words, citing Craies; rejects policy overrides.

holdings.text: The order of termination of service cannot be sustained because of absence of payment on the 25th September.

anchor.surface_text: The question is, whether the order of termination of service can be sustained because of absence of payment on the 25th September.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admission of no payment on date of order (25th Sep 1968), combined with Rule 5 requiring simultaneous payment, renders order ineffective.

holdings.text: The order dated September 25, 1968 terminating the services of the respondent was not in accordance with the provisions of Rule 5.

anchor.surface_text: The only question involved in this appeal is, whether the order dated September 25, 1968 terminating the services of the respondent, a temporary Government servant, was in accordance with the provisions of Rule 5 of the Central Service  Temporary Service  Rules 1965, hereinafter referred to as the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Rule 5 interpretation to facts: no simultaneous payment made, as admitted.

holdings.text: The UP rule differs; payment substitutes without timing condition, unlike Rule 5 where payment conditions forthwith termination.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes State of UP v Dinanath Rai: UP rule lacks 'by payment' simultaneity requirement present in CCS Rule 5.

holdings.text: We need not pause to consider the question as to what would be the effect if there was a bonafide mistake as to the amount which is to be paid.

anchor.surface_text: We need not pause to consider the question as to what would be the effect if there was a bonafide mistake as to the amount which is to be paid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Declines to decide hypothetical on mistake in amount.

precedents.cited_holding: The rule does number say that the pay should be given in cash or by cheque at the time the numberice is issued. Knowing the way the Governments are run, it would be difficult to ascribe this intention to the rule-making authority.

anchor.surface_text: The only question involved in this appeal is, whether the order dated September 25, 1968 terminating the services of the respondent, a temporary Government servant, was in accordance with the provisions of Rule 5 of the Central Service  Temporary Service  Rules 1965, hereinafter referred to as the Rules.

Apart from the authorities which were cited at the Bar, it appears to us that the rule is capable of the only interpretation that the order of termination can be upheld if the requisite amount in terms of the rule was paid into the hands of the employee or made available to him at the same time as he was served with the order.

Apart from the authorities which were cited at the Bar, it appears to us that the rule is capable of the only interpretation that the order of termination can be upheld if the requisite amount in terms of the rule was paid into the hands of the employee or made available to him at the same time as he was served with the order.

anchor.surface_text: We need not pause to consider the question as to what would be the effect if there was a bonafide mistake as to the amount which is to be paid.
